Line 4: Line 4:  
A "moral" may refer to a particular principle, usually as informal and general summary with respect to a moral principle, as it is applied in a given human situation.
 
A "moral" may refer to a particular principle, usually as informal and general summary with respect to a moral principle, as it is applied in a given human situation.
    −
[[philosophy|Philosophers]] talk more about [[ethics]] than morals. Ethics is an intellectual approach to moral issues that asks questions such as how one ought to behave in a specific situation (for example, is [[abortion]] morally permissible? This area of philosophy is more appropriately called applied ethics), how can one justify a moral position (for example, if one thinks one is morally justified in telling a lie to protect someone from harm, how would one go about justifying that position? This area of philosophy is known as normative ethics), and finally, philosophers ask meta-ethical questions concerning the justification of ethics or morality itself (for example, do the terms "good", "evil", "right", "wrong" make sense, and how do we justify the existence of "good" or is it all relative, and morality simply a statement of one's preferences (also known as cultural relativism).
+
The systematic study of morality is a branch of [[philosophy]] called [[ethics]]. Ethics seeks to address questions such as how one ought to behave in a specific situation (for example, is [[abortion]] morally permissible? This area of philosophy is more appropriately called applied ethics), how can one justify a moral position (for example, if one thinks one is morally justified in telling a lie to protect someone from harm, how would one go about justifying that position? This area of philosophy is known as normative ethics), and finally, philosophers ask meta-ethical questions concerning the justification of ethics or morality itself (for example, do the terms "good", "evil", "right", "wrong" make sense, and how do we justify the existence of "good" or is it all relative, and morality simply a statement of one's preferences (also known as cultural relativism).
     
There is, of course, in any society, a divergence between the notion of how we ought to behave and the reality of how we behave; so there is a difference between hypothetical [[pundit (politics)|pundit]]ry and real morality. He whom we call "moral" is moral only after he behaves in accordance with either (if we take the pluralist stance) our perception of "morality", or (if we accept its existence) in the universal human interest.
 
There is, of course, in any society, a divergence between the notion of how we ought to behave and the reality of how we behave; so there is a difference between hypothetical [[pundit (politics)|pundit]]ry and real morality. He whom we call "moral" is moral only after he behaves in accordance with either (if we take the pluralist stance) our perception of "morality", or (if we accept its existence) in the universal human interest.
